title: rx
contents:
mode_edit code
API / rxjs/index

rxlink

Converts the first argument to an observable, then passes that observable to the function in the second argument. The result of that function is then passed to the function in the third argument, and so on. This continues until all functions have been called, and the result of the last function is returned.

rx(source: any, ...fns: UnaryFunction<any, unknown>[]): unknown

Parameters

source any

Any valid observable source.
fns UnaryFunction<any, unknown>[]

Any number of unary functions, starting with a unary function that accepts an observable as its only argument.

Returns

unknown: The result of the last function, or an observable if no functions are provided for the second argument and beyond.

Descriptionlink

This means it can be used for anything involving unary functions, just so long as the first unary function accepts an observable as its argument, and as long as the first argument to rx() is a valid ObservableInput.

This is the same as an ordinary functional pipe, except it has an implicit from as the second argument.

The following are equivalent:

// Where `source` is any valid `ObservableInput`. // A (observable, promise, array, async iterable, etc.) rx(source, map(x => x + 1), filter(x => x % 2 === 0)); pipe(map(x => x + 1), filter(x => x % 2 === 0))(from(source)); pipe(from, map(x => x + 1), filter(x => x % 2 === 0))(source);

Furthermore, rx can be used to create an observable and pipe it in any number of ways. For example:

const subscription = rx( of(1, 2, 3), source => source.subscribe(x => console.log(x)), ); // or even something like this: const promise = rx( of(1, 2, 3), async (source) => { const result = []; await source.forEach(x => result.push(x)); return result; }, });
